column10: Comments

Says they have adopted AER data avilability policy.
The website recommends the ReadMe Template on the ``Social Science Data Editors” website.

All submissions must comply with our Data and Code Availability Policy. Papers that use data that cannot be published can be exempted from the requirement to provide some or all data (if notifying the journal upon submission and in your cover letter), but must otherwise comply with the policy.

The Econometric Society (ES) and its journals, Econometrica, Quantitative Economics, and Theoretical Economics, have the policy to publish papers that include empirical, experimental, and/or simulation results only if the data and code used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and access to the data and code is non-exclusive to the authors.

Authors of these papers must provide, prior to acceptance, raw data, codes, and sufficient documentation to permit the replication of all the results in the paper and in the appendices approved for publication online. They must also provide sufficient information to replicate the process of obtaining this raw data from the original sources and cite all the sources of data appropriately.

The journals of the ES will conduct reproducibility checks for the empirical, experimental, and/or simulation results included in the paper and in the approved online appendices prior to final acceptance.

Requests for an exemption from providing the materials described in this policy, or for restricting their usage, should be stated clearly when the paper is first submitted for review. It will be at the editors' discretion whether the paper can then be reviewed. Exceptions will not be considered later in the review and publication process.

By submitting to any journal of the Econometric Society, authors indicate their acceptance of this Data and Code Availability Policy.

By submitting to the journal, you indicate that you accept the Data Availability Policy. In short, the default rule is that you are required to submit all code and data necessary to reproduce your work, and permit any reader of the journal to use them.

It is the policy of the Journal of Political Economy to publish papers only if the data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers, in particular those that contain empirical work, simulations, experimental work, or numerical computations, must provide to the Journal, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. These will be posted on the JPE site. The editor should be notified at the time of submission if the data used in a paper are proprietary or if, for some other reason, the requirements above cannot be met.
For econometric and simulation papers, the minimum requirement should include the data set(s) and programs used to run the final models, plus a description of how previous intermediate data sets and programs were employed to create the final data set(s). Authors are invited to submit these intermediate data files and programs as an option; if they are not provided, authors must fully cooperate with investigators seeking to conduct a replication who request them. The data files and programs can be provided in any format using any statistical package or software, but a Readme PDF file documenting the purpose and format of each file provided, and instructing a user on how replication can be conducted, should also be provided.

All submissions must comply with our Data and Code Availability Policy. Papers that use data that cannot be published can be exempted from the requirement to provide some or all data (if notifying the journal upon submission and in your cover letter), but must otherwise comply with the policy.

All submissions must comply with our Data and Code Availability Policy. Papers that use data that cannot be published can be exempted from the requirement to provide some or all data (if notifying the journal upon submission and in your cover letter), but must otherwise comply with the policy.

column1: JOURNAL OF THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC ASSOCIATION
column7: Own website* (JEEA), public repositories for larger data packages
column10:
JEEA will publish papers only if any data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers which contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work, must provide to JEEA, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. JEEA endorses DCAS, the Data and Code Availability Standard. These will be posted on the JEEA web site. JEEA’s data and code availability policy is compatible with DCAS and authors are encouraged to follow the Data and Code Availability Standard.
They encourage authors to follow DCAS.

All submissions must comply with our Data and Code Availability Policy. Papers that use data that cannot be published can be exempted from the requirement to provide some or all data (if notifying the journal upon submission and in your cover letter), but must otherwise comply with the policy.

It is the policy of the Journal of Labor Economics to publish papers only if the data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must provide to the Journal, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. These will be posted on the JOLE Web site. The Editor should be notified at the time of submission if the data used in a paper are proprietary or if, for some other reason, the requirements above cannot be met.

The Econometric Society (ES) and its journals, Econometrica, Quantitative Economics, and Theoretical Economics, have the policy to publish papers that include empirical, experimental, and/or simulation results only if the data and code used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and access to the data and code is non-exclusive to the authors.

Authors of these papers must provide, prior to acceptance, raw data, codes, and sufficient documentation to permit the replication of all the results in the paper and in the appendices approved for publication online. They must also provide sufficient information to replicate the process of obtaining this raw data from the original sources and cite all the sources of data appropriately.

The journals of the ES will conduct reproducibility checks for the empirical, experimental, and/or simulation results included in the paper and in the approved online appendices prior to final acceptance.

Requests for an exemption from providing the materials described in this policy, or for restricting their usage, should be stated clearly when the paper is first submitted for review. It will be at the editors' discretion whether the paper can then be reviewed. Exceptions will not be considered later in the review and publication process.

By submitting to any journal of the Econometric Society, authors indicate their acceptance of this Data and Code Availability Policy.

This journal requires and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings, which may also include software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.

All submissions must comply with our Data and Code Availability Policy. Papers that use data that cannot be published can be exempted from the requirement to provide some or all data (if notifying the journal upon submission and in your cover letter), but must otherwise comply with the policy.

column2: Own- JHR Replication and Data Availability Policy
column7: Own website (uwpres) or Harvard Dataverse, ICPSR or similar
column10: Replication and Data Availability: We expect authors to adhere to our replication policy and make available the data and programs to other researchers. If there are special circumstances that make this data availability impossible, you must request an exemption from our replication policy at the time of initial submission, and state the reasons for your request.

The Econometric Society (ES) and its journals, Econometrica, Quantitative Economics, and Theoretical Economics, have the policy to publish papers that include empirical, experimental, and/or simulation results only if the data and code used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and access to the data and code is non-exclusive to the authors.

Authors of these papers must provide, prior to acceptance, raw data, codes, and sufficient documentation to permit the replication of all the results in the paper and in the appendices approved for publication online. They must also provide sufficient information to replicate the process of obtaining this raw data from the original sources and cite all the sources of data appropriately.

The journals of the ES will conduct reproducibility checks for the empirical, experimental, and/or simulation results included in the paper and in the approved online appendices prior to final acceptance.

Requests for an exemption from providing the materials described in this policy, or for restricting their usage, should be stated clearly when the paper is first submitted for review. It will be at the editors' discretion whether the paper can then be reviewed. Exceptions will not be considered later in the review and publication process.

By submitting to any journal of the Econometric Society, authors indicate their acceptance of this Data and Code Availability Policy.

It is an integral and essential part of scientific investigation that results are easily replicated. We will only publish papers if they are accompanied by a complete replication package.  Such a package consists of:  a readme file describing the contents of the package and the version of the software it was written for and the respective versions of extra packages the data used in the analysis, including a complete, transparent and precise documentation describing all variables. If the data is provided in a proprietary format, such as in STATA format, then an ASCII file should also be provided all code necessary to re-produce the tables and figures in the paper as well as supplements and appendices, including the code used to run simulation/Monte Carlo studies (the authors are requested to set a seed so that the exact numbers that are reported can be obtained); if the code uses additional packages that are not part of the standard distribution, then these packages should be included so that the code still runs after many years.

column2: Own- Availability of Data and Computer Code for Published Papers
column10:
Authors of accepted papers are required, before final acceptance, to provide to RED the data and computer code used in generating the results of the paper. It should be sufficient to enable other researchers to replicate the results of the paper.

For papers that use empirical data, authors have to provide the final data sets used to obtain the empirical results of the paper, as well as the computer code(s) used to manipulate the data. A readme.txt file should be included describing how the program(s) can be run. If the final data set was created from other sources, a description of how the final data set was created from the previous sources is also required. This description should be sufficiently detailed to allow other researchers to replicate the construction of the final data set. If possible, the original data should also be provided.
Zimmermann is not titled as “Data Editor’’ on the website, but descriptions on the hyper-referenced webpage of RED implies he is playing such a role (on the limited basis required by RED’s data policy)

The ASA (American Statistical Association) strongly encourages authors to submit datasets, code, other programs, and/or extended appendices that are directly relevant to their submitted articles. These materials are valuable to users of the ASA's journals and further the profession's commitment to reproducible research. Whenever a dataset is used, its source should be fully documented and the data should be made available as on online supplement.

The JIE requires that authors provide a replication folder prior to final acceptance. This replication folder should include:
a readme.pdf file with detailed instructions relevant for replication
all relevant code and data required to replicate all empirical and quantitative results as well as computer simulations included in the paper and its appendices.

Data Availability Policy
It is the policy of the IER to publish papers only if the data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must provide to the Review, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. Starting January 1, 2022, at the time of first submission, authors have to acknowledge the following statement (by clicking an appropriate box on the submission website):

This journal requires and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings, which may also include software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.

This journal requires and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings, which may also include software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.

column7: Mendeley and other Elsevier supported repositories
column10: This journal encourages and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings. To facilitate reproducibility and data reuse, this journal also encourages you to share your software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.

column7: Own website (JDE), and Mendeley Data Repository
column10: Authors are invited to submit these intermediate data files and programs as an option; if they are not provided, authors must fully cooperate with investigators seeking to conduct a replication who request them. Authors must provide a Readme PDF file listing all included. Once the final manuscript has been accepted, the authors will be contacted by the editorial office to request the files. The replication files need to be sent to the editorial office within 5 days of being requested. files and documenting the purpose and format of each file provided, as well as instructing a user on how replication can be conducted

They have a replication section which was introduced under editorship of Baltagi in 2003. It was initially devoted to replication of only own articles, but later extended to a couple of other top journals. They cover replication both in the narrow and wide sense. The current editor of the replication section is Heather Anderson.
The original JAE Data Archive was a pioneering work for the journal, built in the 1990s by Professor James MacKinnon of Queen's University, Canada. Volume 10, No. 1 (1995) of JAE was the first issue in which all papers were accepted subject to the proviso that data be provided. Prof. MacKinnon was the Data Archive Maintainer from 1994 to 2022. In 2022, the JAE Data Archive moved to its new home at ZBW's site (an re3data registered operation).

It is the policy of the IMF Economic Review to publish papers only if the data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must provide to the IMF Economic Review, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication.

These will be posted on the IMF Economic Review website.

column1:
JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION OF
ENVIRONMENTAL AND RESOURCE ECONOMISTS
column10: Data availability policy took effect on July 1, 2017

For econometric and simulation papers, the minimum requirement should include the data set(s) and programs used to run the final models, plus a description of how previous intermediate data sets and programs were employed to create the final data set(s). Authors are invited to submit these intermediate data files and programs as an option; if they are not provided, authors must fully cooperate with investigators seeking to conduct a replication who request them. The data files and programs can be provided in any format using any statistical package or software. Authors must provide a Readme PDF file listing all included files and documenting the purpose and format of each file provided, as well as instructing a user on how replication can be conducted.
column12: discrepancy between own policy and that publicised on Elsevier website

column10: It is an integral and essential part of scientific investigation that results are easily replicated. We will only publish papers if they are accompanied by a complete replication package.  Such a package consists of:  a readme file describing the contents of the package and the version of the software it was written for and the respective versions of extra packages the data used in the analysis, including a complete, transparent and precise documentation describing all variables. If the data is provided in a proprietary format, such as in STATA format, then an ASCII file should also be provided all code necessary to re-produce the tables and figures in the paper as well as supplements and appendices, including the code used to run simulation/Monte Carlo studies (the authors are requested to set a seed so that the exact numbers that are reported can be obtained); if the code uses additional packages that are not part of the standard distribution, then these packages should be included so that the code still runs after many years.

This journal operates a type 3 research data policy (social sciences). Authors publishing in this journal must provide a data availability statement as part of their articles. Authors are encouraged to share their data or other materials underpinning their study, but are not required to do so.

column1: JOURNAL OF MONEY CREDIT AND BANKING
column10: Notes from Vilhuber (2020)

Journal of Industrial Economics encourages authors to share the data and other artefacts supporting the results in the paper by archiving it in an appropriate public repository. Authors should include a data accessibility statement, including a link to the repository they have used, in order that this statement can be published alongside their paper.

column7: Mendeley, ICSPR*, or alternatives (but not authors’ own websites)
column10:
Unless authors are granted an exemption, the Journal of Urban Economics will publish papers only if the data and code used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. At the time a paper is accepted, but before publication, authors of papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must upload a replication folder to a major data repository. That folder should include data, code, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication.
For empirical and simulation papers, the minimum requirement for data/code posting includes (i) the data set(s) used to generate all estimates reported in the paper; (ii) a description of how previous intermediate data sets and programs were employed to create the final data set(s); and (iii) the complete set of code from raw data to final results except where such code would reveal confidential information about the data. Authors are also encouraged to post intermediate data files. If those files are not posted, authors must fully cooperate with subsequent inquiries from individuals seeking to conduct a replication except where a prior data exemption has been granted.

It is the policy of the JLE to publish papers only if the data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must provide to the JLE, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. These will be posted on the JLE Web site.

This journal operates a type 3 research data policy (social sciences). Authors publishing in this journal must provide a data availability statement as part of their articles. Authors are encouraged to share their data or other materials underpinning their study, but are not required to do so.

Economic Development and Cultural Change encourages authors of empirical papers to provide data and analysis sufficient for replication.  Upon acceptance, authors should post the following on EDCC’s Dataverse:      Code and programs that can be used for replication,     Dataset(s) used to run the final models, and     “Readme” files detailing how data and programs are combined to generate the final analysis. Such files should include a description of how intermediate data files were used to create the final dataset.

column9: Wiley Online Library, on behalf of The London School of Economics and Political Science and The Suntory and Toyota International Centres for Economics and Related Disciplines

column10: For empirical, experimental, and numerical papers, authors will be required to upload source files and relevant data files for editorial replicability review as a condition of acceptance. Journal of Financial Econometrics withholds the right to reject papers if underlying data are not provided for editorial review without compelling justification. Authors should request an exemption from replicability review in the cover letter at the point of submission if unable to comply wholly or partially. For the avoidance of doubt, this policy will apply to all original submissions from 13 March 2023 onwards.

column1: JOURNAL OF POLICY ANALYSIS AND MANAGEMENT

column10: The Journal of Economic History requires authors to deposit data and materials with the openICPSR repository (www.openicpsr.org) that allow other researchers to replicate analyses in a published article without any additional information from the author. Authors are also required to include a citation pointing to the data in the reference section of the final version of the article sent to the JEH editors. The openICPSR repository automatically generates a citation when the data are “published.” Deposits should include all data, annotated program code, command files, and documentation that is needed to replicate the findings from a JEH article. Each variable in the data collection should have a set of exhaustive, mutually-exclusive codes. Variable labels and value labels should clearly describe the information or question recorded in that variable. Missing data codes should be defined. Identifying information should be removed from the data to protect confidentiality. Program code and command files should be annotated to facilitate replication and ensure clear correspondence between code and figures, tables, and analyses in the JEH article. For a discussion of best practice in preparing data for sharing, please refer to ICPSR's Guide to Social Science Data Preparation and Archiving, 5th Edition.

column1: JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT
column7: Mendeley, Elsevier’s Data Journal or equivalent
column10:
The Journal of Environmental Economics and Management (JEEM) now requires that authors of published empirical papers to make their data and analysis publicly available and sufficiently documented for replication purposes. With few exceptions, as noted below, authors of papers accepted for publication will be required to post the following on Elsevier's Mendeley website, ELSEVIER's DATA JOURNAL or equivalent data repository:
1. Code and programs that can be used for replication, including any computer programs used to collect experimental or observational data,
2. Dataset(s) used to run the final models, and
3. "Readme" files detailing how data and programs are combined to generate the final analysis. Such files should include a description of how intermediate data files were used to create the final dataset.

column2: Taylor & Francis Basic Data Sharing Policy
column10:
This journal applies the Taylor & Francis Basic Data Sharing Policy. Authors are encouraged to share or make open the data supporting the results or analyses presented in their paper where this does not violate the protection of human subjects or other valid privacy or security concerns.

Authors are encouraged to deposit the dataset(s) in a recognized data repository that can mint a persistent digital identifier, preferably a digital object identifier (DOI) and recognizes a long-term preservation plan. If you are uncertain about where to deposit your data, please see this information regarding repositories.

Authors are further encouraged to cite any data sets referenced in the article and provide a Data Availability Statement.

The World Bank Economic Review requires all authors, where ethically possible, to publicly release all data and software code underlying any published paper as a condition of publication. If data are proprietary or the requirement otherwise cannot be met, this should be noted in a cover letter to the editor on submission. We require that data be presented in the main manuscript or additional supporting files, or deposited in a public repository whenever possible.

This journal requires and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings, which may also include software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.

This journal requires and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings, which may also include software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.
column12: Compare with above, very similar template but statement is required here, only encouraged above

column10:
It is the policy of The Journal of Law, Economics, & Organization to publish papers only if the data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must provide to The Journal of Law, Economics, & Organization, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. These will be posted on the JLEO website.

For empirical and simulation papers, the minimum requirement should include the dataset(s) and programs used to run the final models, plus a description of how previous intermediate datasets and programs were employed to create the final dataset(s). Authors are invited to submit these intermediate data files and programs as an option; if they are not provided, authors must fully cooperate with investigators seeking to conduct a replication who request them. The data files and programs can be provided in any format using any statistical package or software. Authors must provide a "ReadMe "PDF file listing all included files and documenting the purpose and format of each file provided, as well as instructing a user on how replication can be conducted.

This journal requires and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings, which may also include software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.

The journal requires authors to include a data availability statement as part of their article. If no data was generated or analysed, a statement to that effect should be included.
The journal does not require that research data are shared in a repository, although authors are recommended to do so if possible.

In particular, the journal does not require public sharing of quantitative or qualitative data that could identify a research participant unless participants have consented to data release.
This journal operates a type 1 research data policy. The journal encourages authors, where possible and applicable, to deposit data that support the findings of their research in a public repository.

column7: OpenICPSR. Alternatives subject to editor’s approval
column10:
No mention of “DCAS” on their website, but their name is on the DCAS website and their described policy is similar to DCAS.

They seem to have no data editor, but they state that “A member of the editorial board will review the data archive to ensure that it meets the journal requirements.”

column7: Own archive (Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control data archive)
column10: This journal requires and enables you to share data that supports your research publication where appropriate, and enables you to interlink the data with your published articles. Research data refers to the results of observations or experimentation that validate research findings, which may also include software, code, models, algorithms, protocols, methods and other useful materials related to the project.

Manuscripts should provide enough descriptive information about data sets and any sample restrictions so that other researchers could replicate findings. Editors expect authors to retain their data and programs for at least five years after article publication, and to share those data and programs with other researchers wishing to replicate or extend the findings.

Open-ICPSR*, or as an alternative: Mendeley
column10: Explorations in Economic History requires authors of all published papers to deposit the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication prior to publication.

column1: OXFORD BULLETIN OF ECONOMICS AND STATISTICS

column7: Not required/ Harvard Dataverse or similar
column10: JEMS encourages authors to share the data and other artefacts supporting the results in the paper by archiving it in an appropriate public repository. Authors should include a data accessibility statement, including a link to the repository they have used, in order that this statement can be published alongside their paper.

Authors of accepted papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must provide to ALER , prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. All data and do files must be made available at acceptance to ALER where they will be indexed on the ALER website for public access.

NTJ has implemented a policy to publish empirical papers only if the data and analysis are sufficiently documented to allow for replication. With few exceptions, as noted below, authors of papers accepted for publication will be required to post the following on the NTJ website hosted by DATAVERSE:
Code and programs that can be used for replication, including any computer programs used to collect experimental data
Dataset(s) used to run the final models, and
"Readme" files detailing how data and programs are combined to generate the final analysis. Such files should include a description of how intermediate data files were used to create the final dataset.

On acceptance of their paper, authors must submit a complete set of any data used in the paper. Computer code necessary to run a commercial program or the source code of a non-commercial program must also be submitted. The results of the paper must be capable of replication given access to any commercial program used to obtain the results. The data, computer programs, and code will be maintained in the data archive which is linked to the journal’s homepage.

To facilitate the verification and replication of results, authors of accepted papers are expected (on acceptance but prior to publication of the paper) to submit data sets, programs, a full list of data sources, and information on empirical analysis, experiments and simulations that are needed for replication. If the data are not readily available publicly, then this often means that the authors will make them available as an online appendix to the paper, on the OEP webpage.
They talk of a repository maintained by IARIW, but do not specify the link or service
column12:
In the subsection titled “Data Sharing and Data Availability” has written “encourages” data sharing, which according to Wiley’s language means both submitting a data availability statement and sharing data is optional but encouraged:
https://authorservices.wiley.com/author-resources/Journal-Authors/open-access/data-sharing-citation/data-sharing-policy.html
However in the subsection titled “Submission of Data and Computer Code” it says both are required

column7:
openICPSR repository, the Dataverse Project, or an
institutional repository
column10:
The Economic History Review requires all authors to make clear the sources and evidence they use
in order to allow their arguments and results to be evaluated by other researchers.
Where articles employ quantitative data, approaches and techniques that can only be securely
validated through replication, the editors will not publish papers until a replication package
containing the data, any relevant programs and code, and complete and transparent documentation
is made available to any researcher for the purpose of replication. Similarly, where data series are
the main finding of articles, the editors expect authors to make the series available to other scholars
by depositing the series in a digital format at an appropriate repository.
Deposited data should include all data, program code, command files, and related documentation
that is needed to replicate your paper’s findings. All code and command files must be annotated to
make replication simple, with all necessary information about variables etc stated clearly.

This journal “expects” data sharing (for meaning of the terms refer to:
https://authorservices.wiley.com/author-resources/Journal-Authors/open-access/data-sharing-citation/data-sharing-policy.html)

column7: OpenICPSR*, Harvard IQSS, UK Data Archive, Swedish National Data Service and GitHub\

column10:
It is the policy of The Southern Economic Journal to publish papers only if the data used in the analysis are clearly and precisely documented and are readily available to any researcher for purposes of replication. Authors of accepted papers that contain empirical work, simulations, or experimental work must make available on their web site, prior to publication, the data, programs, and other details of the computations sufficient to permit replication. The Editor should be notified at the time of submission if the data used in a paper are proprietary or if, for some other reason, the requirements above cannot be met.

Our policies differ somewhat for econometric and simulation papers, and for experimental papers.

For econometric and simulation papers, the minimum requirement is to make available the data set(s) and programs used to run the final models. Authors are also invited to fully cooperate with investigators seeking to conduct a replication.

For experimental papers, we have a more detailed policy, including requirements for submitted papers as well as accepted papers.

column1: B E JOURNAL OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS & POLICY
